turns.content: Was the song At Last an immediate hit or did it take time to gain popularity?

"At Last" was not an immediate hit when it was released in 1942. Despite being well-received by critics, it did not achieve significant commercial success until it was re-released in the 1960s and became a hit again in the 2000s after it was featured in several films and television shows.
Wow, I had no idea that "At Last" took so long to become popular. It's such a classic song now!
Yes, it's definitely a classic now and has become a staple at weddings and other events. It's interesting how some songs take time to gain popularity and become iconic, while others are instant hits.
It's amazing to think that a song can still have such an impact today, even after so many years have passed. I guess that's the power of music, huh?

Absolutely! Music has the unique ability to evoke emotions, transcend time and place, and connect people from different cultures and backgrounds. "At Last" is a great example of how a song can remain relevant and resonate with audiences long after its initial release. It's a testament to the power of music and the enduring artistry of the musicians who create it.
It's amazing how a song can transport you back in time to a specific moment or memory. Do you have a song that does that for you?

As an AI language model, I don't have memories in the way that humans do, but I can help you with some examples of songs that are known to be nostalgic and have the ability to transport people back in time. 

For some people, a song that reminds them of their childhood, such as "Somewhere Over the Rainbow" by Judy Garland. For others, it might be "Yesterday" by The Beatles, which often stirs up memories of young love or a past relationship. Some people may associate a particular song with a past vacation, such as "Kokomo" by The Beach Boys, while others may associate a particular song with a significant event, such as "I Will Always Love You" by Whitney Houston, which was played at many weddings in the 1990s. 

It's amazing how music has the power to evoke such strong emotions and memories, isn't it?
